Article: Arm has taken a major step to open up its Cortex-M processors as soft IP for low-volume internet of things (IoT) applications by announcing that it will scrap all license fees and royalties for designs based on its M1 and M3 processors across Xilinxâs FPGA portfolio. The two companies said that they are collaborating to offer completely zero-cost access to Armâs soft processor IP, integrated with Xilinx tools and software development solutions to accelerate design starts on FPGA. Offered through the Arm DesignStart program, it will enable developers to simplify development of Arm cores spanning Xilinxâs Spartan, Artix and Zynq portfolios.  Recommended  Xilinx Details SoC-like FPGAs   Arm says it made the cores free in FPGAs due to greater pressure from OEMs to develop flexible, application-optimized designs at a faster pace and with less investment. Asked whether the move is to take on the growth of open-source RISC cores as a route to rapid development of low-volume processor-based SoCs, Phil Burr, director, portfolio product management, Arm, told EE Times, âItâs about making sure that people using Arm have maximum choices.â To meet these demands, Burr said it is crucial for developers to have easy access to the most widely adopted processors and the broadest set of software, tools, and know-how, whether on FPGAs, SoCs, or single-board computers (SBCs). The collaboration enables deployment of heterogeneous compute using a single-processor architecture. For example, a Cortex-M soft IP processor can be used alongside an Arm-based SoC using Cortex-A processors built into the Zynq SoC. This, the company says, will help designers to allocate processing tasks to the right compute engine, whether high-performance Cortex-A, real-time Cortex-M, or custom logic. âThe Cortex-M1 and -M3 can now be implemented directly in the FPGA fabric rather than sitting alongside the FPGA,â said Burr. âOEMs have told us that they want the CPU access across all products so that they can reuse the software. This is important when you consider that software is the biggest part of the development cost.â The Arm soft CPU can now be programmed as part of the FPGA fabric. (Source: Arm)
